article.title: Desmothoracid
article.paragraph: Taxoboxgreenyellow Desmothoracida Museum Histoire Naturelle Geneva Blaschka Clathrulina elegans 21102014.jpg 200px [[Blaschka]] glass model of ''Clathrulina elegans'' [[Eukaryote|Eukaryota]] [[SAR supergroup|SAR]] [[Rhizaria]] [[Cercozoa]]<ref name[[Granofilosea]]<ref name'''Desmothoracida''' [[Richard Hertwig|Hertwig]] & [[Lesser]], 1874 '''Clathrulinidae''' [[Claus]], 1874 Genera see text OrderDesmothoracida, thedesmothoracids, are a group ofheliozoanprotists, usually sessile and found in freshwater environments. The adult is a spherical cell around 10-20 m in diameter surrounded by a perforated organicLorica (biology)lorica, or shell, with many radialpseudopodsprojecting through the holes to capture food. These are supported by small bundles ofmicrotubulesthat arise near a point on thenuclear membrane. Unlike other heliozoans, the microtubules are not in any regular geometric array, there does not appear to be a microtubule organizing center, and there is no distinction between the outer and innercytoplasm.

Reproduction takes place by the budding off of small motile cells, usually with twoflagella. Later these are lost, and the pseudopods and lorica are formed. Typically, a single lengthened pseudopod will secrete a hollow stalk that attaches the cell to the substrate. The form of the flagella, the tubular cristae within themitochondrionmitochondria, and other characters have led to the suggestion that the desmothoracids belong among what is now theCercozoa. This was later confirmed by genetic studies.

As of the year 2000, the order Desmothoracida contained fivegenusgenerawith a total of 10 species.Mikrjukov, K. A. (2000).Taxonomy and phylogeny of Heliozoa. 1. The order Desmothoracida Hertwig et Lesser, 1874.Acta Protozoologica39(2) 81-97.
